entry.title: Combined summary - Mailing List Future
entry.summary:
The email discussions at hand delve into the challenges and considerations of preserving digital discussions on platforms like delvingbitcoin.org, especially when compared to traditional mailing lists. The sender showcases a strong preference for maintaining information in a durable and accessible format, akin to the Linux kernel's use of lore.kernel.org, which allows access to emails dating back to 2001. Despite acknowledging the potential usability of delvingbitcoin.org, concerns are raised about its lack of image support and insufficient authentication methods. The sender advocates for a platform that can secure longevity and ensure that conversations can be carried forward to new services if necessary.
Peter Todd offers valuable insights into the security and credibility of archived content, emphasizing the importance of robust authentication methods like PGP and DMARC, which are standard for email list archives but seem to be missing from delvingbitcoin.org. The reliance on timestamps is criticized as a weaker form of security. Peter Todd suggests that it may not be feasible for delvingbitcoin.org to achieve the level of security provided by email archives. He invites further communication through his personal website, providing specific instructions on how to contact him via email.
Matt Corallo raises an issue with the archiving process using the "mailing list mode" and is open to suggestions and discussions to address this challenge. This highlights the need for alternative methods or refinements to ensure effective archiving. A tentative decision to trial delvingbitcoin.org, evaluating its suitability for machine learning hosting options, is mentioned. Questions regarding the organization of the platform, such as the use of categories versus tags, are under discussion, with feedback sought from community members.
Vincent demonstrates enthusiasm to contribute to a project with machine learning moderation, confident in managing potential issues with spam emails, particularly from Microsoft-hosted services. He also volunteers to assist with hosting duties, indicating a collaborative approach to addressing the technical needs of the project.
The possibility of joining Google Groups without a Gmail account is discussed, presenting both workarounds and limitations. Groups.io is introduced as an alternative platform that respects email functionality while offering migration paths from Mailman. Discourse emerges as a preferred solution due to its ability to integrate images and LaTeX effectively, as well as its organizational features. Its "email list mode" is particularly emphasized for allowing users who prefer email communication to benefit from Discourse's enhanced capabilities.
Lastly, the meeting addressed the upcoming shutdown of the current mailing list and considered various alternatives such as Google Groups, GitHub discussions, and self-hosted mailman instances. There is a commitment to full moderation irrespective of the chosen platform. A dedicated section for lightning discussions offered by AJ on delvingbitcoin.com is also a possible option. A vote is planned at the next meeting to resolve indecision on the matter, and participants are encouraged to attend or respond with their perspectives for consideration.
